Purpose -The purpose of this paper is to investigate how trade openness affects the structural vulnerability of developing countries. The analysis is conducted on both the entire sample of 105 countries as well as two sub-samples, namely least developed countries (LDCs) and non-LDCs. Design/methodology/approach -To perform the analysis, the author employs fixed-effects (within) regressions supplemented by instrumental variables technique based on the two-step generalized methods of moments approach. Findings -The author finds empirical evidence that although trade policy liberalization reduces the structural vulnerability on the entire sample developing countries, no statistically significant effect of such liberalization is obtained either on LDCs or non-LDCs. However, trade policy liberalization appears to reduce countries' exposure to shocks, result that applies to the entire sample as well as the two sub-samples. The author also observes that trade policy liberalization exerts no (statistically) significant effect on the size of shocks that affect developing countries, result that applies to both the full sample and the sub-samples of LDCs and non-LDCs. Research limitations/implications -In the absence of a well-established theoretical framework on how trade openness affects the structural vulnerability of developing, the author adopts a pragmatic approach by drawing upon many insights of Loayza and Raddatz (2007) who study the structural determinants of external vulnerability. Practical implications -Developing countries in general and LDCs in particular could address their structural weaknesses by making optimal use of their trade policies. In particular, they could better use the flexibilities available to them in provisions of the World Trade Organization (WTO)' Agreements. In this respect, the international community, notably donors of the developed world has a key role to play. Originality/value -This is the first study exploring how trade openness, capturing here through trade policy liberalization affects the structural vulnerability of developing countries. Should developing countries, in particular least developed countries (LDCs), fear opening up their economies to international trade? More specifically, would trade policy liberalization contribute to enhancing or reducing these countries' vulnerability to shocks? This paper strives to provide an answer to this question. While trade openness could provide many benefits to countries -especially the poorest -under certain conditions, the international trade literature has also established that it exposes them to exogenous shocks. Countries' vulnerability to shocks has traditionally been captured in the empirical literature by the volatility of aggregate output (see, e.g. Easterly et al., 2001; Haddad et al., 2011; Loayza and Raddatz, 2007; Raddatz, 2007). However, this measure has been criticized as it encompasses not only countries' vulnerability to shocks but also the economic policies implemented to mitigate the effects of these shocks. To assess the impact of trade openness on countries' vulnerability, we take a different approach by using a vulnerability indicator that measures structural vulnerability, that is, countries' vulnerability that does not depend on their economic policies. In so doing, we make a distinction between countries that are classified as LDCs -a category of countries designated by the United Nations as the poorest and most vulnerable to shocks in the world -and those that are not. Our study is close in spirit to that of Loayza and Raddatz (2007) who, in exploring the structural determinants of external vulnerability, measure these according to trade impact in terms of trade shocks on output. To our knowledge, this is the first study to explore the impact of trade openness on developing countries' structural vulnerability. We obtain prima facie evidence that trade policy liberalization in developing countries in general and LDCs in particular has contributed significantly to reducing their economic vulnerability, in particular their exposure to shocks. This could in principle help to dissipate the view of many governments in developing countries, notably in LDCs, that protectionist measures complemented by the strengthening of domestic demand -to spur growth -would be the right solution to protect themselves from the vulnerability of their economies to external shocks. The rest of the paper is structured as follows. Section 2 provides a brief literature review on the concept of economic vulnerability and its association with trade openness. Section 3 describes the model and the econometric methodology and Section 4 discusses the expected effect of the explanatory variables. Section 5 discusses the measurement of the explanatory variables and presents the data sources. Section 6 interprets the estimation results and Section 7 concludes.

2. Economic vulnerability and trade openness The concept of "vulnerability" refers to that of "risk." There are several definitions associated with the concept of "risk" depending on the disciplines in which it is studied. In economics, the concept of vulnerability has generally been approached from both macroeconomic and microeconomic perspectives. The microeconomic perspective places emphasis on the impact of shocks on the well-being of individual households, whereas the macroeconomic perspective focusses on the impact of these shocks on economic growth (see also Seth and Ragab, 2012). Naude et al. (2009) provide a general definition of "vulnerability," considering it to be the risk that a "system" undergoes from negative change due to a "perturbation." In the same spirit, Gallopín (2006) defines "vulnerability" as the likelihood of a system being affected negatively by some sort of perturbation or sudden "shock" going beyond the normal range of variability. Following Essers (2013), in a macroeconomic setting, one can consider the system to be an individual country and the perturbation to be a number of macroeconomic shocks.

More specifically, in the area of macroeconomics, the concept of "economic vulnerability" was defined for the first time in 1990 by the Maltese Ambassador, His Excellency Alexander Borg Olivier, who stated:

[…] such an index is important because it reiterates that the per capita GDP [gross domestic product] of island developing countries is not itself an adequate measurement of the level of development of these countries as it does not reflect the structural and institutional weaknesses and the several handicaps facing island developing countries (Malta Government, 1990, p. 7).

Briguglio (1993, 1995) was then among the first to apply this concept in the context of small island developing states. Since then, many conceptual and empirical studies have been conducted on the issue of economic vulnerability. Since then the concept of macroeconomic economic vulnerability has gained currency. Briguglio et al. (2008, p. 1), for example, define economic vulnerability as "as the exposure of an economy to exogenous shocks, arising out of economic openness." Guillaumont (2009, p. 197) provides a dynamic definition of vulnerability, considering it to be "the risk that economic growth [in a given country] is markedly and extensively reduced by shocks." The empirical literature on the macroeconomic vulnerability of countries has usually considered the variability of output (see, e.g. Ramey and Ramey, 1995) or similar indicators as the manifestation of the vulnerability phenomenon. As far as international trade is concerned, the applied literature has established that under suitable conditions, trade openness is positively associated with growth outcomes (see also Frankel and Romer, 1999). However, the sign of the average effect of trade openness on countries' proneness to shocks (macroeconomic vulnerability) remains an issue of hot debate. The strand of the empirical literature that examines the "destabilizing effects" of trade openness on countries' vulnerability to shocks has tended to use the volatility of aggregate output as a means of capturing the measure of this vulnerability. Some studies (e.g. di Giovanni and Levchenko, 2009; Haddad et al., 2011; Loayza and Raddatz, 2007; Raddatz, 2007) find that an increase in the degree of trade openness leads to higher volatility in outcome variables such as aggregate income, especially in developing countries. Others (e.g. Cavallo and Frankel, 2008; Kose and Yi, 2001) either find no significant relationship between an increase in the degree of trade interdependence and domestic macroeconomic volatility, or just a temporary relationship (see Santos-Paulino, 2010). All this leads Montalbano (2011) to conclude that the applied literature on trade and instability itself gives the impression of instability (this author provides a good critical survey of the empirical literature on the subject matter). The variability of output or similar indicators usually considered the manifestation of the vulnerability phenomenon also capture other factors such as the resilience policies (economic policies) implemented by these countries in the face of shocks or policies to reduce their exposure to shocks. Recognizing the weaknesses of using aggregate output volatility to capture the vulnerability of countries, the United Nations Committee for Development Policy (CDP) has developed and progressively refined (through successive revisions in 2003, 2006 and 2009) an economic vulnerability index (EVI), which captures vulnerability caused by structural factors. Structural economic vulnerability as employed in this study refers to the "retrospective EVI," jointly calculated and updated on an annual basis by the FERDI[2] (see, e.g. Guillaumont and Cariolle, 2011) with the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (UNDESA). The EVI is the result of three components: first, the size and frequency of exogenous shocks, either observed (ex post vulnerability) or anticipated (ex ante vulnerability); second, exposure to shocks; third, the capacity to react to shocks, or resilience. Therefore, structural vulnerability

(that is, the EVI), which results from factors that are independent of a country's current political will, differs from vulnerability deriving from policy, which results from recent policy choices. In other words, an index of structural economic vulnerability is related to structural factors -not policy factors -that are beyond the present control of the country and also influence global vulnerability, mainly through resilience (Guillaumont, 2009). This structural vulnerability index is a composite index of "shocks" and "exposure to shocks"; both indicators are equally weighted. The last update was in November 2013. The structure of this index is provided in Appendix 1. Other macroeconomic vulnerability indicators have been proposed in the empirical literature. The first is that of Baritto (2008), which is termed the Global Vulnerability Index. This index encompasses trade, production structure, reserves and the poverty ratio. It therefore entails both structural and economic policy factors and thus is not suitable for our analysis. Another interesting indicator is that of the International Monetary Fund: as noted by Essers (2013), the most comprehensive and systematic approach to measuring and monitoring developing country vulnerabilities today is embodied in the IMF's Vulnerability Exercise for Low-Income Countries (VELIC) and Vulnerability Exercise for Emerging Economies (VEE) (see, e.g. IMF, 2011). Unfortunately, the results of neither the VELIC nor the VEE are publicly available, at least not at the level of individual developing countries, mainly because of market sensitivity.

3. Model and econometric methodology Our analysis is based upon an unbalanced panel of 105 developing countries (for the list of countries, see Appendix 2), comprising 41 LDCs and 64 non-LDCs (non-LDCs) and covering the period 1995-2011. The countries were chosen on the basis of time coverage for all the variables used in the model, as described below. Given the absence of a complete theoretical model for analyzing structural policies that affect structural vulnerability, our approach is more pragmatic. We estimate an empirical model that draws upon many insights from Loayza and Raddatz (2007) who study the structural determinants of external vulnerability. The model can be described as follows:
Log EV I ð Þ it ¼ a 0 þ a 1 Log TradePolicy ð Þ it þ X itÀ1 G þ m i þ e it (1)

where i is an index capturing the country, i ¼ 1, …, 105; t is an index capturing the time period, t ¼ 1995, …, 2011; EVI represents the measure of a country's structural economic vulnerability; Trade Policy is the measure of the trade policy stance of a given country i (as described below); α 0 , α 1 and Γ are parameters to be estimated; X is a vector of control variables measuring structural policies and structural factors that characterize country i and that will likely influence the effects of trade openness on the EVI variable. These variables include global financial integration or financial openness (denoted by gross financial integration (GFI)), financial development (denoted by FD), and human capital, proxied here by the Human Assets Index (HAI). All these control variables are in "log" form and lagged by one year so that they are predetermined with respect to our dependent variable. μ i are country-specific effects, which could be fixed or random effects. The disturbance ε i,t is assumed to be independently and identically distributed (i.i.d., 0, s
e ), that is, it is assumed not to be correlated with the explanatory variables of the model and its normality is not required (Baltagi, 2002).

We first undertake several diagnostic tests on model (1) over the full sample. These tests include the cross-sectional dependence test, the Hausman test, which takes into account the result obtained in the previous test, the Breusch-Pagan test of heteroskedasticity, and the Wooldridge (2002) test of serial correlation. The dimensions of our panel data set (T ¼ 17 and n ¼ 105) suggest the potential presence of cross-sectional dependence in the data. To check whether fixed effects or random effects are suitable for our analysis, we perform the Hausman test, as suggested by Hoechle (2007), which takes into account the possibility of cross-sectional dependence in our data. This test is a slightly modified version of the panel-robust version of the Hausman test suggested by Wooldridge (2002, p. 288ff). Hoechle's (2007) adaptation of Wooldridge's (2002) test is robust to very general forms of spatial and temporal dependence in the residuals. In addition to the "modified standard Hausman test," we also undertake two further tests, respectively a test for the presence of heteroskedasticity and one for serial correlation in the residuals. If the Hausman test rejects the random effects in favor of the fixed effects, and if our residuals are heteroskedastic and serially correlated, then we estimate model (1) with fixed effects by simultaneously taking into account the possibility of heteroskedasticity, serial correlation, and cross-sectional dependence in the residuals. In other words, we estimate a fixed-effects (within) regression model with Driscoll and Kraay[3] (1998) standard errors (henceforth referred to as FE-DK), which Hoechle (2007) adapted in Stata for unbalanced panels. However, our variable "TradePolicy" could be considered endogenous with respect to the "EVI" variable, especially in real world scenarios under which future shocks to EVI may drive today's policy decisions toward changing trade openness (see also Haddad et al., 2013 for this argument). To address this endogeneity issue regarding our variable of interest, we adopt the instrumental variable approach based on the two-step generalized methods of moments (GMM) technique. This is known to provide more consistent results compared to the simple two-stage least squares procedure. We first use the one-year lagged values of the variable "TradePolicy" as our initial instrument on the premise that the trade policy stance of a country in a given year could depend on its stance in the previous year. In addition, we choose as a second instrument the workers' remittances, expressed as a percentage of GDP. Remittance inflows to countries generally accrue to households, which can save or spend them by purchasing domestic goods and services, thereby potentially increasing domestic prices. As a result, the real exchange rate could appreciate, possibly generating the "Dutch disease," i.e., a negative impact on the economy resulting from foreign currency inflows. In response to this real exchange rate appreciation, which would undermine the competitiveness of the recipient country's economy, governments may be tempted to use trade policy to offset the negative effect of real exchange rate appreciation, that is, they will reduce trade barriers by softening trade measures. Moreover, in countries highly dependent on remittances to finance their budgets and where a non-negligible share of these remittances is used to finance imports, governments may be tempted to lower trade barriers to reduce the costs of imports for their citizens. Against this background, we conjecture that remittances are associated with trade policy liberalization and therefore expect the variable representing remittances, expressed as a share of GDP (denoted by "Remitgdp") to be positively correlated with the variable "TradePolicy." To test whether our two instruments are correlated with our dependent variable, we estimate model (2) by means of FE-DK (as for model 1):
Log TradePolicy ð Þ it ¼ b 0 þ b 1 Log TradePolicy ð Þ itÀ1 þ b 2 Log Remitgdp ð Þ it þ n i þ o it

where i ¼ 1, …, 105; t ¼ 1995, …, 2011; β 0 , β 1 , and β 2 are parameters to be estimated; ν i are fixed-country effects; ω it is the error term. All in all, if the coefficients β 1 , and β 2 are statistically significant at the conventional level, we use the two instruments to perform our instrumental variable (IV) technique through the two-step GMM technique to model Equation (1). It is important to emphasize that in performing the IV two-step GMM procedure, we take account of the likely cross-sectional dependence of residuals by correcting the standard errors following the method suggested by Driscoll and Kraay (1998) (see footnote 3). To sum up, we estimate model (1) using the FE-DK technique, but also take into account the possible endogeneity of our variable "TradePolicy," estimating it by means of the two-step GMM technique where the cross-sectional dependence in residuals is considered. As the "EVI" variable entails two main components, namely the exposure to shocks variable (denoted by "Exposure") and the shock variable (denoted by "Shock"), we also estimate model (1) following the steps described below by replacing the "EVI" variable with each of its components. This allows us to examine how the trade policy implemented by the governments of these countries affects their exposure to shocks (notably the size of this exposure), and whether this trade policy is associated with the rise in the size of the shocks faced by these countries.
4. Expected effect of the explanatory variables on structural vulnerability In this section, we discuss the expected effect of each of the explanatory variables on structural vulnerability in turn.

4.1 Trade policy liberalization It is well known that as trade integration deepens, economies are naturally prone to external shocks. This is one of the most important rationales that militates against developing countries adopting export-led growth strategies. Does this mean that greater openness to trade necessarily increase countries' vulnerability to shocks? At this stage of the analysis, we are still agnostic regarding the expected sign of the average effect of trade openness (connectivity) on the countries' structural economic vulnerability. On the one hand, greater trade liberalization (openness) can come at the expense of structural vulnerability if countries that open up their economies to international trade are exposed to frequent external shocks (uncontrolled by governments) because the benefits from trade do not outweigh the losses due to frequent external shocks. These shocks will in turn push up the countries' structural vulnerability by increasing their exposure to shocks. Therefore a negative effect of trade openness on the structural vulnerability of developing countries can be expected. The detrimental effect of trade openness on exposure to external shocks (leading to a rise in this exposure) can be observed when a weakening of export performance triggers a sudden cessation of capital flows. Eichengreen and Rose (1999), Glick and Rose (1999), and Forbes (2002) provide strong evidence of the role of trade linkages in spreading crisis in regions. On the other hand, we can follow Haddad et al. (2011) and argue that trade openness can reduce countries' structural economic vulnerability if it enhances the possibility of international risk sharing. This can happen through better integration in a broader range of global value chains, and implicit and explicit insurance schemes such as joint ventures, international lending, production diversification, and formal insurance contracts.

Trade openness can also help countries deal with natural and environmental shocks by providing foreign exchanges, thereby reducing, all things being equal, the structural economic vulnerability of these countries. In the same vein, trade openness can reduce countries' exposure to foreign shocks by helping them adjust to a cut-off in international financing (Montalbano, 2011). Rose (2005) provides empirical support for this hypothesis, and Cavallo and Frankel (2008) show evidence that trade openness makes countries less vulnerable to both severe sudden stops and currency crashes. The effect of trade openness on countries' economic vulnerability can be mediated by its degree of export diversification. Melitz (2003) shows that trade openness can induce export diversification by increasing the number of exporters in those countries facing improved export opportunities. In such a situation, opening up an economy to trade can, all things being equal, reduce the country's structural economic vulnerability. However, the Heckscher-Ohlin model suggests that trade openness can increase the profitability of traditional sectors in countries experiencing a concentration of primary commodities, thereby exerting a negative incentive to diversify its exports away from commodities. As a result, exposure to shocks and consequently economic vulnerability will increase. Finally, if trade openness reinforces a country's production specialization and concentration (for instance in the agriculture sector) through the exploitation of its comparative advantage, it could increase the risk of structural vulnerability. Conversely, trade openness could reduce a country's economic vulnerability by increasing technological diffusion and expansion of the potential markets.

4.2 Financial openness Openness in capital account transactions can facilitate risk sharing and enhance capital allocation. Accordingly, it can either increase production specialization and therefore the risk of economic vulnerability, or result in product diversification, which can potentially reduce countries' economic vulnerability. In addition, countries opening up their financial accounts could increase their exposure to external financial shocks and therefore increase their economic vulnerability. The average effect of financial openness on countries' structural economic vulnerability is a priori unknown and may well depend on whether we rely on de facto or de jure measures of financial integration (see the next section for a discussion on this matter).

4.3 Financial development By reducing liquidity constraints, financial development can not only facilitate export diversification by increasing the number of exports but can also act as a risk-sharing scheme when countries encounter shocks. Hence, we can expect a negative effect of financial development on structural vulnerability. In the same spirit, Feeney and Hillman (2001) contend that the strong functioning of domestic financial markets can facilitate the diversification of domestic risk (through hedging opportunities) in the presence of shocks, and consequently reduce a country's economic vulnerability. However, if financial markets, including banks, are reluctant to extend credit when countries face severe shocks, one could expect financial development to generate an increase in structural vulnerability. Financial development could dampen the risk of an increase in economic vulnerability, notably through the country's exposure to shocks, by helping to promote innovation activities.

Manova (2008) shows that the positive effect of financial development will be stronger in sectors with greater requirements for outside finance or fewer collateral assets; only then can financial liberalization induce lower economic vulnerability by financing dependent industries to produce more differentiated products. In contrast, if investors do not want to take risks with untried ventures and decide to concentrate financial resources in existing activities in which the economy has already been shown to be competitive, the development of capital markets could lead to export concentration and increase the risk of economic vulnerability for the country (see also Agosin et al., 2012). Rodrik (1998) noted that if trade increases aggregate risk, it is possible to diversify this risk in purely domestic financial markets. Thus, a degree of international risk sharing is expected to reduce the country's economic vulnerability. That said, Svaleryd and Vlachos (2002) point out that whatever measures we use to capture the degree of domestic financial development, these will capture the effect of international financial integration. Hence, it is possible that the effect of financial development on economic vulnerability absorbs the effect of financial integration and vice versa.

4.4 Human capital An important structural factor with the potential to help countries benefit from trade openness and reduce their structural vulnerability is the level of their human capital. A good level of human capital (captured through the level of education and health) can enhance the ability of nations to create or adapt new technologies (Borensztein et al., 1998). In addition, Bravo-Ortega and de Gregorio (2005) note that human capital can contribute as a direct input in the production process, and complement other factors of production such as physical capital and natural resources. Overall, we can expect a country with a high level of human capital accumulation to take advantage of trade openness to reduce its economic vulnerability, including through increasing export diversification (thereby reducing the country's exposure).

5. Measures of explanatory variables and data sources In this section, we discuss the measures of each of our explanatory variables and present the source of the data associated with the variable concerned.

5.1 Measure of trade openness In the empirical literature, trade openness has been measured in various ways as there is no perfect way to do so. While some researchers use incidence-based indicators, such as the average level of tariffs, the level of export taxes, the percentage of imports subject to nontariff restrictions, or a combination of these partial trade policy instruments (see, e.g. the Sachs and Warner indicator), others use outcome indicators in terms of prices (Dollar, 1992) and quantities, such as trade openness (measured by the ratio of exports plus imports of goods and services in percentage of GDP), which is commonly used in the literature. The drawback of incidence-based measures is that they do not reflect the entirety of trade measures implemented by a country to regulate its trade flows. In addition, a combination of these partial trade policy instruments, such as that proposed by Sachs and Warner, is limited to the extent that the indicator of trade liberalization is a dummy variable, which does not necessarily reflect the intensity or the degree of trade liberalization undertaken by a country. Moreover, such an indicator is not available for many LDCs, the set of countries of interest in this study.

Outcome trade policy indicators related to prices, such as the Dollar-type index, also have their limitations. The Dollar-type index proposed by Dollar (1992) is calculated on the basis of the regression of the real exchange rate on its non-policy determinants. An indicator of trade policy is therefore derived from this regression as the ratio of the actual real exchange rate relative to its predicted value. Such an index would be sensitive to the set of countries used in the regression. The same limitation applies to outcome indicators in terms of quantities, notably the one commonly used in the literature: trade openness measured by the ratio of exports plus imports of goods and services in percentage of GDP. This ratio is not suitable for our analysis as it encompasses geographic and demographic factors (which are also included in our EVI), as well as trade and trade-related policies (the latter comprising economic policies and political factors that are liable to affect trade flows). One could also follow the practice in the empirical literature of regressing the trade share on the non-policy determinants of trade flows (demographic and geographic factors) to discriminate between "natural openness" and "residual openness." The former is the fitted value of the regression, whereas the latter is the residual of the regression and represents the "man-made choices" shaping a country's trade openness. However, "residual openness" considered as a measure of trade policy could be misleading for two reasons: First, it includes not only the effect of trade policies on trade flows, but also the effects on non-trade policies such as economic policies, institutions, and other political factors that influence trade flows. Second, as it is a residual of a regression, it will sum up to zero so that the measure obtained is not "absolute" but "relative," as well as depending on the countries selected in the data set. In this study, we measure our trade policy variable using the "freedom to trade" indicator proposed by the Heritage Foundation and also well used in the empirical literature. This indicator is a component of the Economic Freedom Index[4] developed by the Heritage Foundation, and combines measures of trade taxes, tariff rates and trade barriers, and capital market controls. Despite its drawbacks, it presents the advantage of providing both an annual (starting from the year 1995) "absolute" and not "relative" measure of the degree of trade policy liberalization of a given country, and covers many countries in the world, including LDCs.

5.2 Financial openness Kose et al. (2009) discuss the choice between quantity-and price-based measures of financial integration and argue in favor of quantity-based, i.e., de facto measures. In the early literature, de jure measures, such as those based on the IMF's Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions, have also been used extensively. However, Baltagi et al. (2009) and Friedrich et al. (2013) argue that such measures do not fully capture the degree of enforcement and effectiveness of capital controls, or regulations in other fields that affect capital flows. Moreover, Baltagi et al. (2009) provide a lengthy discussion on de jure vs de facto measures of financial openness and conclude that there are difficulties in settling the debate concerning the theoretical pros and cons of these measures. We opt primarily for a de facto indicator of financial integration in our study. This is because it best suits our aim to capture the extent to which the financial connection of a country with the rest of the world affects its structural economic vulnerability. In addition, a country can open up its financial accounts to the rest of the world without necessarily being affected severely by an external financial shock because its dependence on external financial assets and liabilities is relatively low. Therefore, we

use the standard measure of GFI, defined as the sum of total foreign assets and total foreign liabilities in percentage of GDP. Gross measures of financial integration have the advantage of capturing the risk-sharing benefits of financial integration. The alternative use of total foreign liabilities in percentage of GDP to capture only the financing side of financial integration does not quantitatively or qualitatively change our results[5]. To compute this indicator, we use the External Wealth of Nations Mark II Database, constructed and updated by Lane and Milesi-Ferretti (2007).

5.3 Financial development We measure financial development by the ratio of private credit provided by banks and other financial institutions to GDP (expressed in percent). This variable is drawn from the database of Beck et al. (2000), updated in 2013. The missing data are obtained from the World Development Indicators for 2014. Although there is no single variable to capture the extent of financial development, this financial development index is expected to grasp adequately the developments in the financial sector in LDCs, this sector being characterized by the dominance of the banking sector.

5.4 Human capital Human capital is measured through the HAI, provided by FERDI and used by the United Nations CDP as one of the criteria for the identification and ranking of a country from the list of LDCs. The HAI was calculated by Korachais (2011) up to 2008 and was updated up to the year 2011 in July 2014 by Closset et al. (2014). It measures human capital through an arithmetic average of four indices: the child mortality rate index, the prevalence of undernourishment index, the literacy rate index, and the secondary enrollment gross rate index. All these indices, including the HAI itself, are bounded between 0 and 100 where 0 reflects the lowest level and 100 the highest attainable level.

6. Estimation results and discussion We report the outcome of the diagnostic tests in Table I. It was not possible to performance the cross-sectional dependence test given the unbalanced nature of our panel. However, we believe that there is potentially a contemporaneous correlation between individual characteristics of the panel and subsequently take this into account in our analysis. We therefore perform the Hausman test of fixed vs random effects, as proposed by Wooldridge (2002, p. 288ff).

The Hausman test rejects the null hypothesis of no fixed effects for all specifications except for the specification of model (1) with the variable "shock." This suggests that model (1) should be estimated by fixed effects for specifications with either the variable "EVI" or the variable "Exposure." Notwithstanding the acceptance of the null hypothesis for the specification with the variable "Shock," we estimate it with fixed effects given the endogeneity issue raised above. For all specifications, the Breusch-Pagan test of heteroskedasticity strongly rejects the null hypothesis of homoskedasticity. Furthermore, the Wooldridge test of serial correlation also rejects the null hypothesis of the absence of autocorrelation in the residuals. Given these results, we proceed to estimate model (1) using the FE-DK technique over the full sample, as well as the sub-samples of LDCs and non-LDCs, and alternatively with the dependent variables EVI, Exposure, and Shock. The results of the estimations are reported in Table II. In columns (1), (2), and (3) of this table, we present the results of estimations over the entire sample with, respectively, the variables EVI, Exposure, and Shock. Columns (4), (5), and (6) contain the results for the sub-sample of LDCs with, respectively, the variables EVI, Exposure, and Shock. Finally, columns (7), (8), and (9) contain the results for the sub-sample of non-LDCs with, respectively, the variables EVI, Exposure, and Shock. For the full sample, structural vulnerability appears to be significantly and negatively associated with trade policy at the 5 percent level of statistical significance. However, and surprisingly, the coefficient of this variable is statistically insignificant (at the conventional level) for the sub-samples. Trade policy liberalization exerts a significant and negative effect on the size of countries' exposure to shocks, a result that also applies to the sub-samples of LDCs and non-LDCs. 7. Conclusion In this paper, we investigate the effects of trade openness on the structural economic vulnerability of a set of 105 developing countries, of which 41 are LDCs and 64 are non- LDCs, over the period 1995-2011. To perform our analysis, we use the indicator of trade policy liberalization (namely, freedom to trade internationally) proposed by the Heritage Foundation, together with the EVI developed by the United Nations for the inclusion and ranking of a country in the LDC category. We observe empirical evidence that trade policy liberalization reduces (on average) countries' exposure to shocks, with this result applying not only to the entire sample, but also to LDCs and non-LDCs. However, trade openness does not appear to increase the shocks faced by these countries. Overall, this study shows that several structural policies (trade policy liberalization, financial openness, domestic financial development, and human capital accumulation) could contribute to a significant reduction in structural vulnerability, and notably exposure to shocks in developing countries in general and LDCs in particular, thereby dampening the fears of the governments of many of these countries with regard to opening up their economies, notably to international trade. As far as trade policy in developing countries is concerned, developing countries -in particular LDCs -have at their disposal several flexibility measures (beyond tariff-related measures) in the provisions of World Trade Organization's (WTO) Agreements that they can harness to address the structural weaknesses that hamper their economic development. A survey undertaken by the UNDESA (see Cortez, 2011) shows that many LDCs do not make full use of the flexibility measures afforded in the WTO's Agreements, including the support available to them. The reason for this is the low awareness of existing measures among LDCs, which reflects a lack of full understanding of the agreements and their provisions, as well as the lack of availability of qualified human resources to follow up on complex World Trade Organization legal matters. In this respect, although the responsibility for making use of these measures lies primarily with the governments of LDCs, the international community, notably donors in the developed world, have a key role to play in supporting LDCs, enabling them to seize the opportunities offered by the global trading system to address their structural weaknesses (including reducing their exposure to shocks).
